title: How to Dust Houseplants

steps.headline: Take the plants outdoors.
steps.description: Choose a mild day, during the warmest time. Make sure the plant is not in direct sunlight when you're cleaning it.

steps.headline: Spray the leaves, especially on the undersides.
steps.description: Use a spray bottle, available from garden stores and many hardware stores.

steps.headline: Gauge the force of the spray carefully.
steps.description: Match the spray strength to the fragility of the plant. For instance, a rubber plant will stand far more water pressure than will a begonia.

steps.headline: Allow the plants to drip dry.
steps.description: When dry, take them back into the house.

steps.headline: Take a cotton ball and dip it in a bowl of milk.
Wipe the leaves with the milk dipped cotton ball.
steps.description: This both cleans and leaves the leaves on the plant very shiny and clean.

text: Spraying the Plants Take the plants outdoors. Choose a mild day, during the warmest time. Make sure the plant is not in direct sunlight when you're cleaning it. Spray the leaves, especially on the undersides. Use a spray bottle, available from garden stores and many hardware stores. Gauge the force of the spray carefully. Match the spray strength to the fragility of the plant. For instance, a rubber plant will stand far more water pressure than will a begonia. Allow the plants to drip dry. When dry, take them back into the house. Cleaning Large Leaf Plants Take a cotton ball and dip it in a bowl of milk.  Wipe the leaves with the milk dipped cotton ball. This both cleans and leaves the leaves on the plant very shiny and clean.
